item.title: Building a Static-Site With the Hugo Framework
item.description:
It was not much trouble getting this site up at all. For several years now I have desired to actually launch my website and blog; I really desired to have a place where I could keep all of my thoughts together and orient them around a narrative in order to both help me learn, and (perhaps) help others as well. I had been searching for the longest time for an efficient framework for static-site generation without much avail. I had previously considered using Pelican but was very quickly turned off to the idea because it is written in Python. Python (and the Python Software Foundation) with its numerous known issues when it comes the many intentional breakages between versions as well as all of its 3rd-party dependencies is not a language (nor platform) that I can feel any peace of mind with using. I was searching for something that was far more simple and dependable. I kept my eyes open, but was not keeping a look-out intensively. Yet, it was at this very moment that I stumbled across Hugo.

Needless to say, it was love at first sight; and O bless Fireship for introducing me to it in his ‘Hugo in 100 Seconds’ on YouTube. As soon as I saw the video I dove head first into install and deployment. I followed the quick-start guide on the website and within minutes I had a, albeit simple, static-site spun up in mere minutes. The thing that took me by immediate surprise was the speed with which it was able to generate the static-site content.
